>I found this list of the greatest singers of the 20th Century in "Classic

>CD" (like the magazine, I put the names in reverse order)

>81 Heddle Nash

>80 Ian Bostridge

Oh, *please.* And Rogers Covey-Crump? Talk about self-delusion...

>82 Simon Keenlyside

>76 Thomas Allen

>75 Andreas Scholl

>71 Ileana Cotrubas

>40 James Bowman

>38 Geraint Evans

>23 Peter Pears

Fine singers, but only the our-judgments-are-the-center-of-the-world urbane

provinciality of British musical opinion could place these countrymen and

British favorites/publicity creations on a list of this kind.

Imagine including Cotrubas and Gheorghiu and not (to name six) Favero,

Norena, Bori, Hempel, Nezhdanova or Mason!

>33 Bryn Terfel

Maybe. We'll see.

>50 Eva Turner

>22 Alfred Deller

>14 Janet Baker

>8 Kathleen Ferrier

I would indeed put these on such a list.

In disbelief--

-David Shengold

Lars,

thanks for the effort of posting the list, it's a good item for

discussion.

If anything, the limitations of the listing are symptom of the

lack of culture of many of the so called "critics" and persons of

authority. Someone wrote a gentle rebuke to David Shengold to

the the effect that the list is understandably lacking in

some "obscure" artists.

And one has to make hard choices in the

solemn business of deciding "century" lists, poor little things!

Please! Give me a break! David was right on - if anything he was too

gentle!

Angela Georghiu and Elena Cotrubas but no Zara Dolukhanova and Nadezhda

Obukhova and Marian Anderson.

Generally speaking not a single Russian bass except Chaliapin and

Kipnis (the latter did not sing in Russia anyway). No Reizen, no

Pirogov, no Mikhailov, no Sibiriakov, no Kastorsky. Even "Classic

CD" should have learned about those at school!

No Heinrich Schlusnus, no Pavel Lisitsian. There is no Gino

Bechi, de Luca, Georges Thill, Simoneau, Alarie. Pol Plancon is not on

the list? Fine, they don't know Russians and French and Canadians and

are not too good with Italians but what about Kim Borg and Salminen.

Perhaps someone has published the name of the author of this list.

I certainly would be curious to know who that genius was - and that he

/she hopefully kept their day job before taking up this business of

music-opera expert!

Disgusting!

I for one would choose not one of the American singers Neil mentions if

compiling a list of the 100 greatest singers of the century and I can't

imagine that any serious estimate of great singing would include any of them

(though dull old Morris seems to take some people in as much as the even

more mediocre-voiced Tomlinson does). There have been a great many fine and

even great British singers, but that does not alter the fact that the

musical press there tends to be parochial ("our own such-and-such") in a way

not found in a large multinational country like the United States. Americans

can be and are parochial about many things, but opera singers do not tend to

be one of them, perhaps especially not for those who really know anything

about opera. If anything native singers have usually been treated

automatically as inferior to European imports. See the chapter on Eleanor

Steber in Peter G. Davis' THE AMERICAN SINGER for a good example. Beverly

Sills (to whom Davis is BTW grossly unfair) is a rare counterexample,

someone who was able to use her Americanness to boost her popularity and

exposure here.

I don't think even Malfitano's wildest admirers at Lyric Opera of Chicago

would pretend that she has a great Verdian instrument; go back through old

issues of OPERA magazine and see the claims made for Barstow, Glossop,

Shuard, Fretwell, Bryn-Jones, Dennis O'Neill and the rest.

This is a magazine about CDs, right? These people are supposed to be

professionally aware of the recorded legacy? Many of the world's great

singers unmentioned on this craven list have performed in London, and Tower

Records in Piccadilly seems well stocked with CDs of even more of them. I

think they could be reasonably be expected to know of many finer lyric

sopranos than Ileana ("Oh, but she was a Glyndebourne discovery! Her Tatiana

at the Garden opposite Tom Allen and Gillian Knight lives on in the mind and

heart") Cotrubas.

I think the list is unfair even to many British-based singers. I'd say

Heather Harper and Joan Cross are more important historically and had better

voices than Cotrubas. And while Emma Kirkby may deserve a place in the

history of classical music *marketing*, aren't Margaret Marshall and Lynne

Dawson her superiors in nearly every way?

I'm sorry, but this is a brave stab only at reifying a particular set of

received opinions; some of which will certainly please the advertising

buyers at Decca.

David Shengold

I suspect that this "list" is a compilation of a number of experts each picking

his/her own top twenty, say, (without ranking them) , and then counting up the

votes and assigning points. In this way a performer who made 1/3 of the top

twenty lists (but wouldn't have made the top 200 of the other experts) would

score fairly well, while a singer who only one expert picked in the top twenty,

but all of whom might have picked in the top forty, say, would score very

badly. That is very likely the reason for these ridiculous rankings.

It would be interesting to hear the mathematical basis (to use the term

extremely loosely) for the rankings, Lars, if they are given in the article.

The devil is in the details, when one examines statistics.

Pat Finley

Der Reine Tor

Dear Pat Finley, I haven't got the entire magazine, I only made photocopies

of the pages with the list.

The mag. says that the contributors are "two dozen" of their leading

critics. Quote: "After pooling the hundreds of votes and arguing over

level-pegging artists..."

That's all I got. BTW, I find the list bloody objectionable but not

ridicolous. I think the most fatal error was not to include the basso of the

century (here I go again...) Nicolai Ghiaurov. He deserved Chaliapin's place

at number 16 (at the least).

Other huge errors are the exclusions of Cappuccilli, Gruberovà and Nicola

Ghiuselev.

I agree with you that the exclusion of Merrill was a scandal, but I don't

think the same goes for Corelli and Siepi. Del Monaco? Maybe. He's much

better than Peter Pears...

And even with the deep admiration I have for Scotto (at her youthful best,

mind you), I find myself recalling some other names already that ought to

have been considered at least: (in no special order) Caniglia, Stignani,

Pasero, Cigna, Cerquetti, Stevens, Hempel, Tetrazzini, Galli-Curci, Caballe,

Corelli, Di Stefano, Tucker, Ralf, Ramey, Cole, L.Price, Bergonzi, Carreras

(in his youth), J. De Reszke (one or two of the Maplesons do give us a

haunting melancholy in the phrasing), Arroyo (shame on me :~), Bumbry,

Gencer, Moedl, Schmidt, Lauri-Volpi, Merli, Thill, Paul Kelly (no, really,

his coloratura is quite astonishing and he has a truly appealing timbre),

Ramon Vargas, Stanford Olsen, Uhde, Merrill, Bastianini, Frantz,

Bockelmann -- yup, the line stretches out forever. This *is* impossible!!

:~)

Maybe not every one of these thirty-plus add-ons would make my top hundred,

but boy oh boy. . . . they're all a lot more than just add-ons!! (What

have I let myself in for??)

I believe this was in response to the question asking who are the

authors of this list. I have a further question: who are Terry Blain,

Geoffrey Crankshaw, Neil Evans, Andy Hamilton, Barbara Hammond, Malcolm

Hayes, Julian Haylock, Adrian Jack, Michael Jameson, Robert Layton, Erik

Levi, Jeremy Nicholas, Michael Oliver, Michael Quinn, Paul Riley,

Michael Scott Rohan, Tom Sutcliffe, Joanne Talbot, Michael Tanner, Simon

Trezise, Jonathan Webster, Terry Williams and Barry Witherden?

Is it true that the credentials of each includes having travelled the

globe to all the major opera-producing venues, being well versed in the

vocal arts, the standard repertoire and the arcane, as well as 7 or more

languages employed in opera, having heard 10,000 or 20,000 or 30,000

singers, or more...and the unusual qualification of being well over 100

years old?

The foregoing presumably the case, that is a very valuable list indeed.

What was the point system for quantifying the various artists' places on

the list? In case of a tie, what tilted the ranking in favor of one or

another singer? Coming from a magazine dedicated to a technology in

commercial existence for a bit over 20 years, was the ranking of those

singing only in that time frame? What factors weighed in favor of those

or against those much represented by recordings, or rarely so? What

considerations were accorded singers ill-represented in the first half

of the century?

Post scriptum: what halfwit dreamed up the idea of rankings, and what

idiocy prompted Terry Blain, Geoffrey Crankshaw, Neil Evans, Andy

Hamilton, Barbara Hammond, Malcolm Hayes, Julian Haylock, Adrian Jack,

Michael Jameson, Robert Layton, Erik Levi, Jeremy Nicholas, Michael

Oliver, Michael Quinn, Paul Riley, Michael Scott Rohan, Tom Sutcliffe,

Joanne Talbot, Michael Tanner, Simon Trezise, Jonathan Webster, Terry

Williams and Barry Witherden to take part in and have their names

associated with such a garbage-driven enterprise?

"why am i taking on like this? my kid ain't even been born yet?"

--o. hammerstein II, "Carousel"

Dear Gail-- "What about our own Frank Sale, Walter Midgely, Edgar Evans and

Tom Swift???"

But seriously: if you can bear to keep yourself from those James Morris CDs

for a day or two, do investigate the recordings (esp. Handel, Mozart,

Schubert) of Anthony Rolfe Johnson. I am also very partial to Ian Partridge.

Both are indeed among my favorite active singers, and so neither requires

"historical digging"!

David Shengold

exception of Gobbi, who was placed far too high, made the list.
